column1: HELLP syndrome is a group of symptoms that occur in pregnant women who have: - H: hemolysis (the breakdown of red blood cells) - EL: elevated liver enzymes - LP: low platelet count
In women with preeclampsia or eclampsia, the condition develops in 10 to 20% of pregnancies.
Many women have high blood pressure and are diagnosed with preeclampsia before they develop HELLP syndrome.
In some cases, HELLP symptoms are the first warning of preeclampsia.

Symptoms include: - Fatigue or feeling unwell - Fluid retention and excess weight gain - Headache - Nausea and vomiting that continues to get worse - Pain in the upper right or mid part of the abdomen - Blurry vision - Nosebleed or other bleeding that will not stop easily (rare) - Seizures or convulsions (rare)

During a physical exam, the doctor may discover: - Abdominal tenderness, especially in the right upper side - Enlarged liver - High blood pressure - Swelling in the legs Liver function tests (liver enzymes) may be high.
A CT scan may show bleeding into the liver.
Your health care provider may induce labor by giving you medicines to start labor, or may perform a C-section.

You may also receive: - A blood transfusion if bleeding problems become severe - Corticosteroid medicines to help the baby's lungs develop faster - Medicines to treat high blood pressure - Magnesium sulfate infusion to prevent seizures
You should also let your health care provider know right away if you have symptoms of this condition.
When the condition is not treated early, up to 1 of 4 women develop serious complications.
A clotting disorder that leads to excess bleeding (hemorrhage).

- Fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema) - Kidney failure - Liver hemorrhage and failure - Separation of the placenta from the uterine wall (placental abruption) After the baby is born, HELLP syndrome goes away in most cases.
